metadata.titleEn: Daily 1-km all-weather land surface temperature dataset for the China's landmass and its surrounding areas (TRIMS LST; 2000-2022)
metadata.description: Land surface temperature (LST) is one of the important parameters between the Earth's surface and the atmosphere. LST is not only a sensitive indicator for measuring climate change factors and an important prerequisite for grasping climate change patterns, but also a direct input parameter for many models, and has a wide range of applications in many fields such as meteorology, environmental ecology, hydrology, and climate. With the deepening of research and refinement of related studies, there is an urgent need for all - weather LST based on satellite remote sensing. The dataset was generated based on enhanced Reanalysis and Thermal infrared remote sensing Merging (E-RTM) method. The primary input data for the method are Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products and GLDAS data, with ancillary data including NDVI and surface albedo. The evaluation results show that the dataset not only has good image quality and seamless spatial accuracy, but also has a high degree of agreement in amplitude and spatial distribution with the 1 km Terra/Aqua MODIS LST product, which is now widely used in academia day by day. The mean bias deviation (MBD) of the data set is 0.09 K and 0.03 K and the standard deviation of bias (STD) is 1.45 K and 1.17 K for daytime and nighttime when using MODIS LST as a reference. There is no significant difference between sky and clear sky conditions. The temporal resolution of this dataset is four observations per day, the spatial resolution is 1 km, and the time span is 2000-2022; the spatial scope includes the main land areas of China (including Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan, excluding the South China Sea islands for the time being), and the surrounding areas (72°E-135°E, 19°N-55°N). The abbreviation of this dataset is TRIMS LST (Thermal and Reanalysis Integrating Moderate-resolution Spatial-Seamless LST. In order to reduce the related user data download and processing effort, the TRIMS LST - TP (Daily 1-km all-weather land surface temperature dataset for Western China (TRIMS LST-TP; 2000-2022) V2) synchronous National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: LST data are in GEOTIFF and NETCDF formats, each file is about 35MB, and the data of different years are stored in folders named "year", which are stored in two folders, one for daytime and the other for nighttime. The specific file naming method is "TRIMS_Aqua/TRIMS_Terra+year+DOY+D/N.tif", in which DOY stands for Day of the Year, D/N stands for Day/Night, such as TRIMS_Aqua2020001D.tif.
Data format: Integer
Usage: It can be read and subsequently processed directly by GIS software or matlab, etc. The image value/100=surface temperature value (two decimal places are retained);
Data resolution: 4 times per day, 1 km.
Data time: corresponds to the instantaneous transit time of MODIS pixels, see the data description document for details of the processing.
Key parameters of the dataset:
(1) Projection mode: Albers equal area
(2) Missing values: Uniformly labelled with 0.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features and attributes of a land surface temperature dataset that integrates satellite thermal infrared remote sensing and reanalysis data?
Feature Specification.Answer: high frequency and low frequency temperature components, spatial correlation of land surface temperature, seamless spatial coverage, Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products, GLDAS data, auxiliary data like vegetation indices and surface albedo, high image quality and accuracy, consistency in amplitude and spatial distribution, temporal resolution of four times daily, spatial resolution of 1 km, time span from 2000 to 2022, specified geographic region

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of a dataset that integrates satellite thermal infrared remote sensing and reanalysis data for land surface temperature?

Comparison.Question: How does the enhanced satellite thermal infrared remote sensing-reanalysis data integration method for land surface temperature compare to traditional MODIS LST products in terms of spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The enhanced method for land surface temperature has a spatial resolution of 1 km and temporal resolution of four times daily, spanning from 2000 to 2022. It provides high-quality, seamless spatial data that has high consistency in magnitude and spatial distribution with the daily 1 km Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products. The average biases compared to MODIS LST are 0.09K during the day and -0.03K at night, with standard deviations of 1.45K and 1.17K respectively.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on the quality and accuracy of land surface temperature data when integrating satellite thermal infrared remote sensing with reanalysis data, compared to using only satellite data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of satellite thermal infrared remote sensing with reanalysis data results in a dataset that has high image quality and accuracy. It provides a seamless spatial coverage and maintains high consistency in both amplitude and spatial distribution when compared to the widely used daily 1 km Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products. The mean bias error (MBE) is 0.09K during the day and -0.03K at night, with a standard deviation of 1.45K and 1.17K, respectively, indicating improved precision over using only satellite data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of integrating satellite thermal infrared remote sensing and reanalysis data for developing an all-weather land surface temperature dataset in the context of climate and environmental research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to accurately reflect the energy interactions between the Earth's surface and the atmosphere, provide a sensitive indicator for climate change, serve as a crucial input for various models in fields such as meteorology, climate, ecology, and hydrology, and meet the urgent demand for high-quality all-weather land surface temperature data. The integration aims to leverage the high-frequency and low-frequency components of surface temperature from satellite infrared data and reanalysis data, as well as their spatial correlation, to reconstruct a high-quality dataset that is spatially seamless and consistent with widely used MODIS LST products.
